image.altText: A head and shoulder shot of Barry Cable standing in a courtyard.

items.synopsis: Barry Cable is ordered to pay $800,000 after a judge finds he groomed and sexually abused a young girl, starting when she was aged just 12, with sexual contact and harassment continuing for decades until the woman was in her mid-30s.

title.children: Woman unlikely to receive any money after judge finds she was sexually abused by Barry Cable

image.altText: Peter Dutton in the prime minister's courtyard

items.synopsis: Peter Dutton says he was made aware of another allegation against senator David Van and that he should quit parliament, following claims made by senator Lidia Thorpe and former senator Amanda Stoker in recent days.

title.children: Peter Dutton says senator David Van should quit parliament, after another allegation raised with him

image.altText: Picture of a sign saying caution with an open pit coal mine and power station in the background

items.synopsis: A supposed exemplar of energy security and prescience just last year, Western Australia is now facing calls for a shake-up of its policies amid soaring prices and supply strains.

title.children: Australia's energy woes shift west as state's power and gas prices head skywards

image.altText: portrait shot of Andrea in front of tiles in kitchen

items.synopsis: Andrea was five when she discovered she was adopted and she's struggled with the fallout for decades. It's why she's determined to see a trauma support service created for forced adoption survivors.

title.children: 'I would just go in a spiral': Why Andrea can't celebrate her birthday and has vowed she never will

image.altText: a photo of a phone that shows 'SOS"

items.synopsis: Claire Harrison says she's still recovering from losing her identity and tens of thousands of dollars by mobile porting fraud, where scammers port your mobile number to another device.

title.children: 'Terrifying' phone porting scam stealing millions but cybersecurity experts say it's unavoidable

image.altText: A man is lowered into a mine shaft

items.synopsis: Pictures document a painstaking search for clues in WA's remote Mid-West region, as police return to the century-old mineshaft where the body of an amateur prospector was found eight years ago.

title.children: Police dig up mine shaft in hope of solving baffling WA outback murder mystery

image.altText: LIz Indrans

items.synopsis: A report by Swinburne University of Technology found 10 companies that trialled a four-day work week continued it after a pilot, with four organisations adopting the change permanently.

title.children: These employers have introduced four-day work weeks and 'can't think of a downside'

image.altText: Liberal Senator David Van

items.synopsis: Two women ended up in tears in the Senate this week, as the Brittany Higgins imbroglio exploded yet again and in the process claimed a scalp, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: A spectacular fall as Liberals chase the uncatchable

image.altText: Broome Hospital signage outside.

items.synopsis: Aggression against nurses at Broome Hospital has doubled in the past two years as patients battle long wait times.

title.children: Broome Hospital staff place average of 1.5 code black calls a day as aggression, threats increase

image.altText: A crowd of people in a auditorium.

items.synopsis: WA's Aboriginal Affairs Minister says concerns raised by farmers and landholders about the state's post-Juukan Gorge heritage reforms are misplaced.

title.children: WA government stands firm on Aboriginal heritage reforms despite growing calls for delay

image.altText: Chief Justice Susan Kiefel.

items.synopsis: The first woman to be the chief justice of the High Court, Susan Kiefel announces her early retirement from the highest court in the land.

title.children: Trailblazing justice Susan Kiefel to retire early from the High Court

image.altText: an aerial photo of a roundabout

items.synopsis: Albany in Western Australia has a population of about 40,000 and manages to survive without traffic lights. But it does have a whopping 54 roundabouts.

title.children: This regional city takes pride in having no traffic lights, but is it a safer approach?

image.altText: A man stands in front of a lectern.

items.synopsis: Upon handing down a year-long jail term, a County Court judge has described Ballarat real estate agent Richard Hayden, who embezzled nearly $800,000 from clients, as a man of "otherwise unblemished character".

title.children: Real estate agent who stole from clients to fund good end-of-life for wife jailed

image.altText: Sign for Brisbane Supreme and District Court buildings.

items.synopsis: The man was sprayed in the face with an aerosol can of wasp killer before a lighter was ignited after swinging a baseball bat.

title.children: Man sentenced for burning ex-girlfriend's new partner with 'improvised flamethrower'

image.altText: Kiwi crossing in New Zealand

items.synopsis: New Zealand was among the first developed economies to start increasing interest rates, and it is yet to see inflation in its target zone. This is how the country compares to Australia.

title.children: New Zealand is officially in a recession. These charts show how Australia compares

image.altText: A middle-aged man with one eye swollen shut, a cut on his nose and eye bruising. He is wearing a neck brace.

items.synopsis: Jim Cullen's ordeal was not over when help finally arrived after a crash in the NT that left his mates fearing for his life. Rather than an emergency airlift, he then had to endure a 60km trip along a rough dirt road to an airstrip.

title.children: Motorcyclist's six-hour wait in 'absolute agony' sparks push for more outback airstrips

image.altText: Aerial photo of the surf break at Snapper Rocks

items.synopsis: A remarkable feat of engineering is the secret to the Gold Coast's iconic surf break.

title.children: Is the Gold Coast's Superbank a miracle of mother nature or a masterpiece of human engineering?

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

items.synopsis: AGL's bottom line is set to get a big boost while consumers are hit with rising energy bills. And local shares are trading higher today, after a Wall Street rally. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: AGL shares soar as energy giant set to double profits, ASX climbs and Europe lifts rates

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Westpac has lowered its growth forecasts growth forecasts to 0.6% in 2023 and 1.0% in 2024. The bank now expects a higher peak cash rate of 4.6 per cent and a delay to the first rate cut in 2024 from February to May. Westpac's previous forecast was growth of 1 per cent in 2023 to be followed by 1.5 per cent in 2024, based on a peak cash rate of 4.1 per cent. Westpac Chief Economist Bill Evans' now expects household consumption to grow by just 0.3 per cent in 2023 and 0.6 per cent in 2024. "This consumption profile is consistent with the very weak measures of Consumer Sentiment we have seen since the onset of high inflation and rising interest rates in 2022," Mr Evans said. Mr Evans said the forecasts mean per capita spending recessions in both 2023 and 2024 of -1.5% in 2023 followed by -1.0% in 2024. It also implies GDP per capita recessions of -1.2% in 2023 and -0.6% in 2024. A per capita recession is when the economy continues to grow but living standards decline. "Consumer spending prospects, in the face of high inflation and  sharply higher interest rates, would be even weaker were it not  for the substantial savings buffer that households accumulated  during the pandemic and the strong starting point for jobs," Mr Evans said. "The  tightest labour market conditions in 50 years and still elevated  job vacancies are providing clear support to household incomes  and spending, but also give those households coming under  more intense financial pressure more scope to make adjustments."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Westpac downgrades growth forecast, tips cash rate of 4.6 per cent

children.content: Westpac has lowered its growth forecasts growth forecasts to 0.6% in 2023 and 1.0% in 2024.
The bank now expects a higher peak cash rate of 4.6 per cent and a delay to the first rate cut in 2024 from February to May.
Westpac's previous forecast was growth of 1 per cent in 2023 to be followed by 1.5 per cent in 2024, based on a peak cash rate of 4.1 per cent.
Westpac Chief Economist Bill Evans' now expects household
consumption to grow by just 0.3 per cent in 2023 and 0.6 per cent in 2024.
"This consumption profile is consistent with the very weak measures of Consumer Sentiment we have seen since the onset of high inflation and rising interest rates in 2022," Mr Evans said.
Mr Evans said the forecasts mean per capita spending recessions in both 2023 and 2024 of -1.5% in 2023 followed by -1.0% in 2024.
It also implies GDP per capita recessions of -1.2% in 2023 and -0.6% in 2024.
A per capita recession is when the economy continues to grow but living standards decline.

"Consumer spending prospects, in the face of high inflation and  sharply higher interest rates, would be even weaker were it not  for the substantial savings buffer that households accumulated  during the pandemic and the strong starting point for jobs," Mr Evans said.

"The  tightest labour market conditions in 50 years and still elevated  job vacancies are providing clear support to household incomes  and spending, but also give those households coming under  more intense financial pressure more scope to make adjustments."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX is up 0.6 per cent to 7,216. Utilities, energy and tech are the sectors leading the gains on the benchmark index as we get into afternoon trade. AGL's still on top after announcing a massive profit upgrade largely driven by the expensive energy prices, we're all paying at the moment. It comes after the AER recently approved electricity price hikes of 25 per cent for consumers.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Utilities, energy and tech boost ASX 200

children.content: The ASX is up 0.6 per cent to 7,216.
Utilities
energy
and
tech
are the sectors leading the gains on the benchmark index as we get into afternoon trade.
AGL's

still on top after announcing a massive profit upgrade largely driven by the expensive energy prices, we're all paying at the moment. It comes after the AER recently approved electricity price hikes of 25 per cent for consumers.
ASX gains and declines at 12:40pm AEST
(ASX)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Sales of new homes increased by 9.4 per cent in May, but purchases are still 40 per cent lower than the year before and 25 per cent down on pre-pandemic levels. HIA Senior Economist Tom Devitt said new home sales remain at "depressed levels." "This indicates that the slowdown in home building that is underway will continue for at least the next year," Mr Devitt said. “The most significant contraction in sales is in New South Wales where customers are more sensitive to rises in the cash rate. “Cancellations also remain elevated at a rate of 25 per cent in the last quarter. This means, for every four new projects a builder is recording, a previous project is being cancelled. “The RBA’s rate increases will continue to hold down new sales and cause further cancellations as finance becomes unobtainable for an increasing number of buyers. “The significant increase in the cost of land and construction across all jurisdictions over the past two years is compounding the impact of higher interest rates. " Mr Devitt also blamed the National Construction Code which came into effect this year (which means houses need to be more energy efficient) for driving up construction costs and dampening demand. “This combination of factors will see home building continuing to contract for at least the next 12 months to its lowest level in more than a decade,” Mr Devitt said. He said sales of new homes in the three months to May 2023 compared to the same time last year are still down in most large states, led by New South Wales (-63.6 per cent), and followed by Queensland (-52.9 per cent), Victoria (-46.6 per cent) and South Australia (-29.5 per cent). Western Australia saw the only increase over the year, up by 19.4 per cent.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: HIA says housing construction to fall to lowest levels in a decade

children.content: Sales of new homes increased by 9.4 per cent in May, but purchases are still 40 per cent lower than the year before and 25 per cent down on pre-pandemic levels.
HIA Senior Economist Tom Devitt said new home sales remain at "depressed levels."
"This indicates that the slowdown in home building that is underway will continue for at least the next year," Mr Devitt said.
“The most significant contraction in sales is in New South Wales where customers are more sensitive to rises in the cash rate.
“Cancellations also remain elevated at a rate of 25 per cent in the last quarter. This means, for every four new projects a builder is recording, a previous project is being cancelled.
“The RBA’s rate increases will continue to hold down new sales and cause further cancellations as finance becomes unobtainable for an increasing number of buyers.
“The significant increase in the cost of land and construction across all jurisdictions over the past two years is compounding the impact of higher interest rates. "
Mr Devitt also blamed the National Construction Code which came into effect this year (which means houses need to be more energy efficient) for driving up construction costs and dampening demand.
“This combination of factors will see home building continuing to contract for at least the next 12 months to its lowest level in more than a decade,” Mr Devitt said.

He said sales of new homes in the three months to May 2023 compared to the same time last year are still down in most large states, led by New South Wales (-63.6 per cent), and followed by Queensland (-52.9 per cent), Victoria (-46.6 per cent) and South Australia (-29.5 per cent).
Western Australia saw the only increase over the year, up by 19.4 per cent.
Private new house sales
(HIA )

image.altText: a man wearing dark glasses holding a smoke and leaning up against a car

items.synopsis: The father of a mentally ill man who was fatally shot by police in country New South Wales says he could have de-escalated the situation if officers had alerted him.

title.children: Father tells inquest police scared son 'like caged animal' before fatal shooting

image.altText: A suburban house is strewn with damaged cars and debris under dark clouds

items.synopsis: A tornado rips through the Texas town of Perryton, reportedly killing three people, injuring dozens more and causing widespread damage as another in a series of fierce storms carves its way through America's South.

title.children: Tornado devastates US town, reportedly killing three people and injuring dozens

image.altText: Indigenous woman Jacinta Nampijinpa Price speaks to a forum, with and Indegenous elder and child flanked either side.

items.synopsis: With a referendum on the Voice to Parliament approaching in the second half of the year, there's one myth about the proposed body which refuses to die, despite repeated debunking.

title.children: This myth about the Voice pushed by No campaigners including Jacinta Nampijinpa Price refuses to die

image.altText: An old looking hospital

items.synopsis: The incidents occurred when the patient, identified only as "Mr J", was admitted to the Women's and Children's Hospital's mental health ward in August 2021, and breached basic restraint and seclusion rules, a report released today has found.

title.children: Young patient was kept secluded for hours, restrained face down at Adelaide children's hospital

image.altText: Man with a beard and black shirt

items.synopsis: Amid sub-zero overnight temperatures, the ADF is joining an urgent search to find 28-year-old Luke Fergusson lost in bushland north-west of Brisbane since last Friday.

title.children: Mother's plea to find autistic son Luke, missing for a week in Qld bush

image.altText: A scan of a photo shows Florence Charleston holding a baby

items.synopsis: How Florence Charleston wound up dead and buried in a shallow grave hundreds of kilometres from her home remains a mystery.

title.children: DNA match identifies human remains found stuffed in garment bag 45 years ago

image.altText: Man wearing a dark, collared shirt stands in front of some students' paintings, smiling.

items.synopsis: New details emerge about the child sexual abuse charges levelled against a Ballarat school teacher as he appears in court.

title.children: Bail extended for Ballarat teacher facing 34 child sex offence charges

image.altText: A pair of smiling newlyweds at their reception.

items.synopsis: Madison Tougher, who married Steven Tougher weeks before his alleged murder, has welcomed their daughter into the world, the NSW Ambulance service has announced.

title.children: 'Great joy out of great sadness' as slain paramedic's wife gives birth to their baby girl

image.altText: Patrick Dangerfield pumps his fist in celebration

items.synopsis: Geelong confirms star midfielder Patrick Dangerfield played on with a cracked rib and partially collapsed lung in the club's loss to the Power.

title.children: Cats confirm Patrick Dangerfield played on with partially collapsed lung

image.altText: Ice in the ocean

items.synopsis: This year has already produced record-high ocean temperatures, record-low Antarctic sea ice, and global air temperatures well above average all year.

title.children: Sudden surge of record-high temperatures could propel 2023 as warmest year on record

image.altText: A mug shot of a man

items.synopsis: He's already serving three life sentences after confessing to a trio of underworld murders. Now Abuzar Sultani has been sentenced for his role in the death of a teenager in Sydney 10 years ago.

title.children: Judge describes hit man's rehabilitation as 'pointless exercise' as he jails him for fourth Sydney murder

image.altText: A smiling young girl with ginger hair, wearing a school uniform.

items.synopsis: Police believe that Breanna Horsten, who has not been seen for 10 days, is with her father and that a 24-year-old woman may be in their company.

title.children: Search for 10-year-old girl expands as possible link to second missing person revealed

image.altText: Screenshot from a video showing a police car and people holding up a tarp by the road

items.synopsis: Video from the scene showed firefighters spraying water on a burning white vehicle that was in a ditch to the side of the road.

title.children: At least 15 people dead in Canada as truck hits bus carrying elderly people

image.altText: An aerial photo shows an overcrowded boat on a blue sea.

items.synopsis: As authorities continue to look for the hundreds of missing passengers, nine survivors accused of being part of the smuggling ring behind the tragedy are arrested.

title.children: Children among the hundreds missing after migrant boat sinks off Greece

image.altText: A Hwasong-18 intercontinental ballistic missile is launched into the air as part of a North Korea's test launch

items.synopsis: The punitive sanctions against North Korea come after South Korean military reported its neighbour fired two short-range missiles off its east coast in response to military drills staged by South Korean and US troops.

title.children: US targets North Korea's missile development in fresh sanctions

image.altText: A group of women run around a track.

items.synopsis: Aussie runners push their global rivals at the Bislett Games, and claim Australian records with strong performances in Oslo.

title.children: Jess Hull and Olli Hoare power to Australian records at the Bislett Games in Oslo

items.synopsis: Ukraine says it is pushing Russian forces back in places along the southern and eastern frontlines, while Moscow announces plans for elections in occupied areas in its latest bid to signal it is in control.

title.children: Drone footage reveals scale of Russian destruction in Bakhmut as Ukraine presses counteroffensive
